The Act titled "Federal Physicians Comparability Allowance Amendments of 2000" makes the authority permanent. The Act titled "Federal Physicians Comparability Allowance Amendments of 2000" permanently repeals certain sections of the Federal Physicians Comparability Allowance Act of 1978 and makes technical amendments to title 5, United States Code. The Act repeals sections of the Federal Physicians Comparability Allowance Act of 1978 and makes technical amendments to title 5, United States Code regarding the treatment of allowances as part of basic pay for retirement purposes. The Act amends the definition of Basic Pay in title 5, United States Code to include physicians comparability allowances. It also adds rules for computing physicians comparability allowances under the Civil Service Retirement System. The Act amends the definition of Basic Pay in title 5, United States Code to include physicians comparability allowances. No part of a physicians comparability allowance is considered basic pay unless the individual has completed at least 15 years of service as a Government physician. Amounts received as a physicians comparability allowance are treated as basic pay only for service performed after the enactment of this subsection. The percentage of allowable service performed by a Government physician varies based on years of service: 
- Less than 2 years: 0%
- At least 2 but less than 4 years: 25%
- At least 4 but less than 6 years: 50%
- At least 6 but less than 8 years: 75% At least 8 years: 100% The text discusses the treatment of physicians comparability allowance as basic pay for computing annuities and survivor annuities. It also defines a government physician under section 8331 of title 5, United States Code. The text discusses the treatment of physicians comparability allowance as basic pay for computing annuities and survivor annuities for Federal Employees' Retirement System. It defines a government physician under section 8331 of title 5, United States Code. For the purposes of computing annuities and survivor annuities for Federal Employees' Retirement System, physicians comparability allowance is treated as basic pay if certain conditions are met. This applies to amounts received by individuals attributable to service performed after the enactment of this subsection. Government physicians' percentage allowable service performed after enactment of subsection:
- Less than 2 years: 0%
- At least 2 but less than 4 years: 25%
- At least 4 but less than 6 years: 50%
- At least 6 but less than 8 years: 75% After 8 years, government physicians can perform 100% of allowable services. Government physicians can receive 100% of physicians comparability allowance as basic pay for computing annuities and survivor annuities.
